abstract.p: New York Mets are reportedly ready to make offer to Mike Piazza (S)

block.p: As is his policy, General Manager Steve Phillips of the Mets would not articulate how he planned to approach an attempt to sign Mike Piazza. But a person with knowledge of Phillips's strategy confirmed yesterday that Phillips would fly to Southern California early next week to make an offer to the All-Star catcher and his representatives.
I have no comment, Phillips said yesterday.

As is his policy, General Manager Steve Phillips of the Mets would not articulate how he planned to approach an attempt to sign Mike Piazza. But a person with knowledge of Phillips's strategy confirmed yesterday that Phillips would fly to Southern California early next week to make an offer to the All-Star catcher and his representatives.
I have no comment, Phillips said yesterday.

Mets ownership has made no secret of its desire to retain Piazza, a sentiment Nelson Doubleday, the team's co-owner, reiterated on Wednesday. Piazza rejected a six-year, $84 million deal from the Los Angeles Dodgers before he was traded to Florida on May 15 and then to the Mets on May 22. He can become a free agent 15 days after the World Series.
Piazza batted .329 with 32 homers and 111 runs batted in for the Dodgers, Marlins and Mets this season; .348 with 23 homers and 76 r.b.i. in 109 games with the Mets.
Neither Piazza nor his main representative, Dan Lozano, could be reached for comment yesterday. Both are vacationing and are not scheduled to return to California until Sunday.
